reasoning:
1. Circle of Competence: I’m afraid Amazon sits outside my wheelhouse. I stay in businesses I thoroughly understand – consumer staples, insurance, railroads – and generally steer clear of complex, rapidly changing technology outfits (Apple’s the exception because I view it as a consumer products business). Amazon’s mix of e-commerce, logistics networks, and cloud computing isn’t in my circle.  
2. Competitive Moat: While Amazon has scale, Prime memberships, and AWS network effects, its core retail business is a low-margin commodity that lacks durable pricing power. AWS is a bright spot, but it faces stiff competition from Microsoft and Google.  
3. Management Quality: I admire Jeff Bezos’s vision and I’ve long respected the talent at Amazon. But massive capital spending on fulfillment centers and data centers with low returns on equity (–0.2% ROE here) raises questions about the discipline in capital allocation. Good managers think like owners, but Amazon burns cash reinvesting at thin margins.  
4. Financial Health & Consistency: The numbers aren’t pretty. Negative owner earnings, inconsistent ROE (only 3 of 10 periods above 15%), a score of 4 on fundamentals but 0 on consistency. In my view, strong businesses report reliable earnings year after year – this one doesn’t.  
5. Valuation vs. Intrinsic Value: The DCF spits out a negative intrinsic value (–$78 per share) and a negative margin of safety. I won’t pay up for a business that, by conservative estimates, destroys value.  
6. Long-Term Prospects & Red Flags: Amazon may be around in two decades, but what matters to me is return on capital over time. Persistent low returns, heavy debt financing, and fickle consumer tastes raise red flags.  
7. Portfolio Comparison: I’d far rather own a Coca-Cola or a See’s Candies – even at a fair price – than a complex, low-return operation at any price. In a world of limited capital, I see better opportunities sticking to my circle.  
Conclusion: I’d pass on Amazon today. It’s a business I don’t fully grasp, with uneven returns and a valuation that offers no margin of safety.

fundamental_analysis.details: Weak ROE of -0.2%; Conservative debt levels; Strong operating margins; Current ratio data not available

consistency_analysis.details: Inconsistent earnings growth pattern; Total earnings growth of 101.1% over past 10 periods

moat_analysis.details: Inconsistent ROE: only 3/10 periods >15%; Decent operating margins (avg: 28.1%) suggest some competitive advantage

book_value_analysis.details: Moderate book value per share growth

management_analysis.details: No significant new stock issuance detected; No or minimal dividends paid

details: Using three-stage DCF: Stage 1 (-3.5%, 5y), Stage 2 (-1.7%, 5y), Terminal (2.5%)
